studies.title: Swedish two-county trial: impact of mammographic screening on breast cancer mortality during 3 decades
studies.authors_full: Tabár L, Vitak B, Chen THH, et al.
studies.study_design_detail: 29-year follow-up of community-level cluster RCT comparing mammography invitation vs none
studies.population: Women aged 40-74 in two Swedish counties
studies.key_finding: Mammography screening invitation reduced breast cancer mortality by 27-31% (RR 0.69-0.73); NNS 414-519 for 7 years to prevent 1 death
studies.notes: Swedish Two-County Trial

studies.title: General health checks in adults for reducing morbidity and mortality from disease
studies.authors_full: Krogsbøll LT, Jørgensen KJ, Gøtzsche PC
studies.study_design_detail: Systematic review of 19 RCTs comparing health checks vs no checks
studies.key_finding: General health checks do NOT reduce all-cause, CV, or cancer mortality; increase diagnoses but not outcomes
studies.notes: Direction '−' = contrarian/null finding

studies.title: Screening for cervical cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis
studies.authors_full: Peirson L, Fitzpatrick-Lewis D, Ciliska D, Warren R
studies.study_design_detail: Systematic review and meta-analysis; MEDLINE/Embase/Cochrane search
studies.key_finding: Cervical screening reduces incidence and mortality by 60-90%; single lifetime screening reduces mortality RR 0.65

studies.title: Systematic skin cancer screening in Northern Germany
studies.authors_full: Breitbart EW, Waldmann A, Nolte S, Capellaro M, Greinert R, Volkmer B, Katalinic A
studies.journal: Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology
studies.study_design_detail: SCREEN project; population-based skin cancer screening in Schleswig-Holstein
studies.population: Citizens ≥20 years with statutory health insurance
studies.key_finding: Population-based melanoma screening reduced melanoma mortality by 48% (men 47%, women 49%)
studies.notes: SCREEN project; led to Germany's national screening program

studies.title: Screening and prostate cancer mortality: results of the European Randomised Study of Screening for Prostate Cancer (ERSPC) at 13 years of follow-up
studies.authors_full: Schröder FH, Hugosson J, Roobol MJ, et al.
studies.study_design_detail: ERSPC multicentre RCT; PSA screening vs no intervention; 13-year follow-up
studies.key_finding: PSA screening reduces prostate cancer mortality by 21%; 1 death prevented per 1,410 men screened; substantial overdiagnosis concern

effect_sizes.description: Number needed to screen over 13 years

studies.notes: ERSPC trial; shared decision-making recommended due to overdiagnosis

studies.title: Screening men for abdominal aortic aneurysm: 10 year mortality and cost effectiveness results from the randomised Multicentre Aneurysm Screening Study
studies.authors_full: Thompson SG, Ashton HA, Gao L, Scott RAP; MASS Group
studies.study_design_detail: MASS trial; 10-year follow-up; ultrasound screening vs no screening
studies.key_finding: AAA screening reduces AAA-related mortality by 48% (RR 0.52); 155 AAA deaths in screened vs 296 in control

effect_sizes.description: 48% reduction in AAA-related mortality at 10 years

studies.notes: MASS trial; one-time ultrasound screening

studies.title: Periodontal systemic associations: review of the evidence
studies.authors_full: Linden GJ, Lyons A, Scannapieco FA
studies.study_design_detail: Critical appraisal of periodontal-systemic disease associations
studies.key_finding: Periodontitis associated with 14-19% increased cardiovascular disease risk; bidirectional relationship suggested
studies.notes: EFP/AAP Workshop

studies.title: Global prevalence of glaucoma and projections of glaucoma burden through 2040: a systematic review and meta-analysis
studies.authors_full: Tham YC, Li X, Wong TY, Quigley HA, Aung T, Cheng CY
studies.study_design_detail: Bayesian meta-analysis of 50 population-based studies
studies.key_finding: Global glaucoma: 76M in 2020, 50% undiagnosed; projected 111.8M by 2040; highest POAG prevalence in Africa (4.2%)

studies.title: Reduced Lung-Cancer Mortality with Low-Dose Computed Tomographic Screening
studies.authors_full: National Lung Screening Trial Research Team; Aberle DR, Adams AM, Berg CD, et al.
studies.study_design_detail: Multicentre RCT; 33 US centers; low-dose CT vs chest radiography
studies.key_finding: Low-dose CT screening reduces lung cancer mortality by 20% in heavy smokers (247 vs 309 deaths per 100,000 person-years)
studies.notes: National Lung Screening Trial

studies.title: Meta-analysis of how well measures of bone mineral density predict occurrence of osteoporotic fractures
studies.authors_full: Marshall D, Johnell O, Wedel H
studies.study_design_detail: Meta-analysis of 11 prospective cohort studies (~90,000 person-years, 2,000+ fractures)
studies.population: Women with BMD measurements followed for fractures
studies.key_finding: Each SD decrease in BMD increases fracture risk 1.5-fold (RR 1.5, 95% CI 1.4-1.6); hip fracture risk increases 2.6-fold per SD decrease
studies.notes: Foundation for DEXA screening guidelines

studies.title: Age-related decline in peak oxygen uptake: Cross-sectional vs. longitudinal findings. A review
studies.authors: Jon Magne Letnes, Bjarne M Nes, Ulrik Wisløff et al.
studies.journal: International Journal of Cardiology Cardiovascular Risk Prevention
studies.population: Healthy adults; sedentary vs active populations
studies.effect_size: ~10% per decade decline in sedentary, ~5% in active
studies.key_finding: Longitudinal studies show larger VO2max declines than cross-sectional; physical activity significantly attenuates the rate of decline.

studies.title: Controlled endurance exercise training and VO2max changes in older adults: a meta-analysis
studies.authors: Guoxin Huang, Catherine A Gibson, Zebulon V Tran, William H Osness
studies.key_finding: Controlled endurance training produces significant VO2max improvements in older adults; mitochondrial trainability remains intact with aging.

studies.title: Sinus node disease and arrhythmias in the long-term follow-up of former professional cyclists
studies.authors: Stefan Baldesberger, Urs Bauersfeld, Rolf Candinas et al.
studies.effect_size: 10% AF/flutter prevalence in cyclists vs 0% in controls
studies.key_finding: Former elite endurance athletes show elevated atrial fibrillation risk, demonstrating a paradoxical arrhythmia risk with extreme endurance exercise.

studies.title: Epidemiology and Cardiovascular Benefits of Physical Activity and Exercise
studies.authors: Michael Y Mi, Andrew S Perry, Vaishnavi Krishnan, Matthew Nayor et al.
studies.sample_size: Synthesis of meta-analyses and cohort data
studies.population: General population, sedentary to highly active
studies.effect_size: 30-40% lower mortality with consistent physical activity
studies.key_finding: Comprehensive evidence shows benefits of vigorous physical activity substantially outweigh risks, including atrial fibrillation; 30-40% mortality reduction vs sedentary.

studies.title: Validity of Cooper's 12-minute run test for estimation of maximum oxygen uptake in male university students
studies.effect_size: r = 0.93 correlation between distance and VO2max
studies.key_finding: Cooper's 12-minute run test shows high validity (r=0.93) for predicting VO2max, making it a practical field assessment tool.

studies.title: Multidimensional Sleep Health: Definitions and Implications for Cardiometabolic Health
studies.authors: Marie-Pierre St-Onge, Brooke Aggarwal, Julio Fernandez-Mendoza et al.
studies.effect_size: Multidimensional sleep assessment superior to duration alone for CVD risk
studies.key_finding: AHA statement establishing that multidimensional sleep health (duration, regularity, timing, continuity) is comprehensively linked to cardiometabolic outcomes.

studies.title: Apolipoprotein B vs Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol and Non-High-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol as the Primary Measure of Apolipoprotein B Lipoprotein-Related Risk: The Debate Is Over
studies.authors: Allan D Sniderman, Ann Marie Navar, George Thanassoulis
studies.sample_size: Review of multiple cohort studies (>500,000 participants)
studies.population: General population and high-risk cardiovascular cohorts
studies.effect_size: ApoB superior to LDL-C and non-HDL-C for CVD risk prediction across all discordance analyses
studies.key_finding: ApoB is a more accurate measure of atherogenic lipoprotein burden than LDL-C and should be the primary target for lipid-lowering therapy. European Society of Cardiology 2019 endorsed ApoB as superior.

studies.title: Low-density lipoproteins cause atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. 1. Evidence from genetic, epidemiologic, and clinical studies
studies.authors: Brian A Ference, Henry N Ginsberg, Ian Graham et al.
studies.effect_size: Each 1 mmol/L lower ApoB lipoproteins → 54% lower CHD risk over lifetime
studies.key_finding: Causal relationship between ApoB-containing lipoproteins and ASCVD is established beyond reasonable doubt. Cumulative lifetime exposure determines risk, supporting early and sustained lipid lowering.

studies.title: Lipoprotein(a) as a cardiovascular risk factor: current status
studies.authors: Børge G Nordestgaard, M John Chapman, Kausik Ray et al.
studies.effect_size: Lp(a) >50 mg/dL (>~120 nmol/L) associated with 2-3× increased CVD risk; ~20% of population affected
studies.key_finding: Lp(a) is an independent, causal, genetically determined risk factor for CVD. Recommended screening at least once in lifetime, especially in high-risk individuals.

studies.title: Major lipids, apolipoproteins, and risk of vascular disease
studies.authors: Emanuele Di Angelantonio, Nadeem Sarwar, Philip Perry et al.
studies.effect_size: HDL-C: each 15 mg/dL increase → 22% lower CHD risk; TG: each 88 mg/dL increase → 37% higher CHD risk (partially attenuated by HDL adjustment)
studies.key_finding: HDL cholesterol and triglycerides are independently associated with CHD risk. TG/HDL ratio captures both dimensions of atherogenic dyslipidemia.

studies.title: Prediction of coronary heart disease using risk factor categories
studies.authors: Peter WF Wilson, Ralph B D'Agostino, Daniel Levy et al.
studies.effect_size: Composite risk factors predict 10-year CHD risk: highest quintile has 5-10× risk vs lowest quintile
studies.key_finding: Multiple risk factors (BP, cholesterol, HDL, diabetes, smoking) have multiplicative effects on CHD risk. A composite approach to cardiovascular risk assessment outperforms single-marker screening.

studies.title: Prevalence of Optimal Metabolic Health in American Adults: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 2009-2016
studies.authors: Joana Araújo, Jianwen Cai, Robert E Stevens
studies.effect_size: Only 12.2% of Americans met all 5 metabolic health criteria; 87.8% had at least one metabolic abnormality
studies.key_finding: Fewer than 1 in 8 American adults are metabolically healthy using blood glucose, triglycerides, HDL-C, blood pressure, and waist circumference criteria. Prevalence declined from 19.9% to 12.2% over the study period.

studies.title: The Metabolic Syndrome and Cardiovascular Risk: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
studies.authors: Samuel Mottillo, Kristian B Filion, Jacques Genest et al.
studies.journal: Journal of the American College of Cardiology
studies.effect_size: Metabolic syndrome associated with 2× CVD risk (RR 2.35), 1.5× all-cause mortality (RR 1.58)
studies.key_finding: Metabolic syndrome doubles cardiovascular disease risk and increases all-cause mortality by 58%. Individual components (elevated triglycerides, low HDL, elevated glucose) each independently predict CVD events.

studies.title: Hyperinsulinemia as a long-term predictor of death: prospective population-based Malmö Preventive Project
studies.authors: Bo Hedblad, Peter Nilsson, Lars Janzon, Göran Berglund
studies.effect_size: Highest insulin quartile: HR 1.58 for all-cause mortality; HR 1.54 for cardiovascular mortality
studies.key_finding: Fasting hyperinsulinemia independently predicts all-cause and cardiovascular death, even after adjusting for glucose, BMI, and traditional risk factors. Insulin resistance is detectable years before glucose abnormalities appear.

studies.title: Banting Lecture 1988: Role of insulin resistance in human disease
studies.effect_size: Defined insulin resistance as common pathway linking hyperinsulinemia, glucose intolerance, high triglycerides, and low HDL
studies.key_finding: Landmark paper establishing insulin resistance (Syndrome X, now Metabolic Syndrome) as the central mechanism linking elevated triglycerides, low HDL, hyperglycemia, and hypertension — all driven by hyperinsulinemia.

studies.title: Is the current definition for diabetes relevant to mortality risk from all causes and cardiovascular and noncardiovascular diseases?
studies.effect_size: Fasting glucose ≥126: HR 1.81 for all-cause mortality; impaired fasting glucose (110-125): HR 1.21
studies.key_finding: Fasting glucose shows a graded relationship with mortality risk starting from normal range. Even impaired fasting glucose (110-125 mg/dL) carries 21% higher mortality vs normal levels.

studies.title: Glycated haemoglobin A1c as a risk factor of cardiovascular outcomes and all-cause mortality in diabetic and non-diabetic populations: a systematic review and meta-analysis
studies.authors: Cavero-Redondo I, Peleteiro B, Álvarez-Bueno C, Rodriguez-Artalejo F, Martínez-Vizcaíno V
studies.authors_full: Cavero-Redondo I, Peleteiro B, Álvarez-Bueno C, Rodriguez-Artalejo F, Martínez-Vizcaíno V
studies.key_finding: Optimal HbA1c for lowest all-cause mortality: 5.0-6.0% in non-diabetics, 6.0-8.0% in diabetics. Risk increases significantly above these thresholds.

studies.title: HbA1c and Risks of All-Cause and Cause-Specific Death in Subjects without Known Diabetes: A Dose-Response Meta-Analysis of Prospective Cohort Studies
studies.authors: Zhong GC, Ye MX, Cheng JH, Zhao Y, Gong JP
studies.authors_full: Zhong GC, Ye MX, Cheng JH, Zhao Y, Gong JP
studies.key_finding: In non-diabetic subjects, higher HbA1c is a predictor of increased all-cause and CVD mortality. Each 1% increase above optimal increases cardiovascular mortality risk by 20-30%.

studies.title: Serum uric acid and risk of cardiovascular mortality: a systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis of cohort studies of over a million participants
studies.authors: Li M, Hu X, Fan Y, Li K, Zhang X, Hou W, Tang Z
studies.authors_full: Li M, Hu X, Fan Y, Li K, Zhang X, Hou W, Tang Z
studies.key_finding: Elevated uric acid significantly associated with increased CVD mortality (HR 1.45, 95% CI 1.33-1.58). Relationship stronger in women. Non-linear dose-response pattern.

studies.title: Uric acid lowering improves insulin sensitivity and lowers blood pressure: a meta-analysis of randomized parallel-controlled clinical trials
studies.authors: Huang Y, Chen C, Hu J, Xu X, Li Q, Guo M
studies.authors_full: Huang Y, Chen C, Hu J, Xu X, Li Q, Guo M
studies.journal: Therapeutic Advances in Endocrinology and Metabolism
studies.key_finding: Uric acid-lowering therapy significantly improves insulin sensitivity and lowers blood pressure in hyperuricemia patients, confirming the causal link between uric acid and metabolic dysfunction.

studies.title: The Triglyceride/HDL Ratio as a Surrogate Biomarker for Insulin Resistance
studies.authors: González-Chávez A, Elizondo-Argueta S, Gutiérrez-Reyes G, León-Pedroza JI
studies.authors_full: González-Chávez A, Elizondo-Argueta S, Gutiérrez-Reyes G, León-Pedroza JI
studies.key_finding: TG/HDL ratio is a cost-effective surrogate biomarker for insulin resistance with significant predictive value, even in non-obese individuals, challenging the conventional association of IR solely with obesity.

studies.title: Hyperuricemia and the risk for coronary heart disease morbidity and mortality: a systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis
studies.authors: Li M, Hou W, Zhang X, Hu L, Tang Z
studies.authors_full: Li M, Hou W, Zhang X, Hu L, Tang Z
studies.key_finding: Hyperuricemia associated with increased CHD morbidity (RR 1.13) and mortality (RR 1.27). Effect stronger in women. Each 1 mg/dL increase in uric acid increases CHD mortality by 13%.
Every 10 mmHg reduction in systolic BP significantly reduces major CV events, coronary heart disease, stroke, and heart failure; benefits consistent across starting BP levels
studies.authors_full: Ettehad D, Emdin CA, Kiran A, Anderson SG, Callender T, Emberson J, Chalmers J, Rodgers A, Rahimi K
studies.title: Blood pressure lowering for prevention of cardiovascular disease and death: a systematic review and meta-analysis
studies.study_design_detail: Systematic review and meta-analysis of 123 RCTs
studies.population: Adults with and without prior CVD
studies.notes: Supports BP lowering but establishes context for edge barrier: excessively low BP (hypotension <100) not beneficial

studies.key_finding: J-curve relationship exists between blood pressure and cardiovascular outcomes; excessively low diastolic and systolic BP increases adverse events, especially in patients with coronary artery disease
studies.authors_full: Messerli FH, Mancia G, Conti CR, Hewkin AC, Kupfer S, Champion A, Kolloch R, Benetos A, Pepine CJ
studies.title: Dogma Disputed: Can Aggressively Lowering Blood Pressure in Hypertensive Patients With Coronary Artery Disease Be Dangerous?
studies.study_design_detail: Post-hoc analysis of INVEST trial
studies.population: Hypertensive patients with coronary artery disease (n=22,576)

effect_sizes.description: Nadir diastolic BP < 70 mmHg vs 70-80 mmHg

studies.notes: Primary evidence for BP edge barrier — supports that BP too low is harmful (J-curve). Note: actual publication 2006, commonly cited as foundational J-curve evidence.

studies.key_finding: U-shaped association between HDL-C and all-cause mortality: both extremely low and extremely high HDL-C (>97 mg/dL in men, >135 mg/dL in women) associated with increased mortality
studies.authors_full: Madsen CM, Varbo A, Nordestgaard BG
studies.title: Extreme high high-density lipoprotein cholesterol is paradoxically associated with high mortality in men and women: two prospective cohort studies
studies.study_design_detail: Two independent prospective cohort studies (Copenhagen City Heart Study + Copenhagen General Population Study)

effect_sizes.description: Men with HDL > 97 mg/dL vs reference (73 mg/dL)
Women with HDL > 135 mg/dL vs reference (89 mg/dL)

studies.notes: Primary evidence for HDL edge ceiling barrier at 120 mg/dL

studies.key_finding: Intensive glucose control (target 81-108 mg/dL) increased 90-day mortality compared to conventional control (target <180 mg/dL) in critically ill patients; severe hypoglycemia (<40 mg/dL) strongly associated with death
studies.authors_full: The NICE-SUGAR Study Investigators; Finfer S, Chittock DR, Su SY, Blair D, Foster D, Dhingra V, Bellomo R, Cook D, Dodek P, Henderson WR, Hébert PC, Heritier S, Heyland DK, McArthur C, McDonald E, Mitchell I, Myburgh JA, Norton R, Potter J, Robinson BG, Ronco JJ
studies.title: Intensive versus Conventional Glucose Control in Critically Ill Patients
studies.study_design_detail: Multicenter RCT across 42 hospitals
studies.population: Adults admitted to ICU, expected stay ≥3 days
studies.notes: Supports glucose edge barrier — excessively low glucose increases mortality. Study in ICU patients, but hypoglycemia risks are generalizable.

Consistent sleep timing and death risk

6 hours of sleep is associated with 12% higher mortality
Long sleep (≥9h) associated with 30% higher mortality
Most regular sleepers have 20-48% lower mortality
Regular sleep-wake timing predicts mortality more strongly than duration
Sleep regularity is a stronger predictor of mortality risk than sleep duration
Regularity is the single most impactful sleep behavior for longevity
Sleep deprivation alters immune cells and increases disease risk
Non-restorative sleep: 23% higher all-cause mortality, 48% higher CV mortality
Difficulty falling asleep: 13% higher all-cause, 20% higher CV mortality
6h/night for 14 days = cognitive impairment of 48h total sleep deprivation
RU SATED framework: 6 dimensions of sleep health
Alertness dimension reflects whether sleep fulfilled core biological functions
Long sleep (≥9h) associated with 39% higher all-cause mortality
Social jet lag associated with increased cardiometabolic risk
Weekend catch-up sleep not associated with reduced mortality
Magnesium reduced sleep onset latency by ~17 minutes
~50% of Western adults are magnesium-deficient
Ashwagandha: SMD -0.59 for sleep quality improvement
Ashwagandha ≥600mg/day improved sleep onset and PSQI
Glycine 3g before bed improved sleep quality via thermoregulation
Caffeine reduces total sleep by 45 min; minimum 8.8h cutoff
Light therapy significantly improved sleep maintenance
Sleep efficiency highest at 20-25°C
Warm shower/bath 1-2h before bed: ~36% sleep onset reduction
CBT-I improvements last up to 12 months post-treatment
Wearables detect >90% of sleep epochs vs PSG
Consumer trackers show variable sleep stage accuracy
